title: Avoid Mike Pence's mistakes on religious freedom: experts
text:
The controversial laws were amended after protests, with an estimated cost to the economy of the state capital of Indianapolis of more than $US60 million ($89.4 million).

The Coalition's draft bill may provide more rights for religious people than the rest of the community and set up challenges for human resources and legal management within workplaces, the pair's submission says.

"Attention should be paid to how the bill can better fit within the existing system of discrimination law, rather than seeking to supersede it," it said.

"Indiana still carries an assumption of bigotry, even though the law was repealed almost five years ago.

"Australia has done good work to protect the fair go at home and abroad, but we believe this bill will gather international attention that could jeopardise this. This could call into question Australia's human rights record and negatively impact the tourism industry."

Misty Farquhar said the draft bill "will formalise existing social power imbalances, which will then act as permission for individual discrimination".

Mr Liveris said confusion over conflicts of rights should be expected if the bill is passed by Parliament.

"And there will likely be test cases to answer these questions. But also mediation would likely increase for workplace matters around equal opportunity issues, which can be costly in both process and compensation.

"Until these issues are resolved, religious freedom could be a lawyers picnic with business – and investors and shareholders – picking up the bill."

Human Rights Law Centre executive director Hugh de Kretser has warned doctors' rights must not frustrate non-discriminatory health care in Australia.

He said the bill prioritised the interests of doctors who may conscientiously object to providing services, such as an abortion or contraception.

“Australia needs stronger protections from discrimination for people of faith, but the current bill fails to strike the right balance. It’s good that the government has released these reforms in draft form so that the flaws can be fixed to ensure legislation that can be welcomed.”

Equality Australia believes the draft introduces religious exemptions to Australia’s race and disability discrimination acts for the first time.

“Exemptions to these long-standing anti-discrimination laws are completely unacceptable. No religious belief should overwhelm the right of a person to live, work, study, and access healthcare with dignity," chief executive Anna Brown said.

The Australian Human Rights Commission told the consultation overriding existing discrimination laws was not warranted and would set a concerning precedent from Parliament.
description: Scott Morrison wants debate in Parliament on new religious discrimination laws by Christmas. Experts say it's a potential legal minefield.
